data.text: Contents
Introduction
The purpose of this document is to outline how the Emergency Operating List will be resourced and the processes that apply to booking patients and prioritising the NCEPOD list order.

To ensure that patients booked to the NCEPOD Emergency list are clinically managed in an appropriate and consistent manner. To ensure there is a clear route for booking patients to the NCEPOD Emergency list that takes proper account of individual clinical needs.
Scope
The purpose of this document:
The Emergency Operating Theatre (NCEPOD Theatre) is available 24 hour a day, weekdays and at weekends to perform urgent and emergency surgery.
This policy applies to all patients requiring emergency surgery  hours a day, 7 days a week.
Definitions

table_items.text: National Confidential Enquiry into Patient Outcome and Death

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Surgical team are responsible for;
Booking Patients.
Ensuring patients that are booked are adequately prepared for Surgery and appropriate consent has been sought.
Ensuring that all relevant clinical information accompanies the patient.
Ensuring that Emergency Theatre team are available for team brief and attend Emergency board briefings.
Anaesthetic team are responsible for:
Assessing patients prior to surgery.
Ensuring handover at change of anaesthetic teams is comprehensive.
Undertaking the ‘Sign In' WHO Check when patient arrives, ensuring that all patient documentation is present and correct before commencing any procedure.
Theatre Team leader/Co-ordinator is responsible for:
Ensuring details are correctly entered into Theatreman.
Ensuring equipment is available (prior to sending for the patient).
Ensuring skill mix is appropriate and escalating to floor co-ordinator where this has not been achieved.
Time out:

Scrub Nurse/Practitioner is responsible for ensuring that all WHO checks are undertaken with the team that are delivering the care that the patient requires. Any member of the Theatre team may request a ‘STOP' during any part of the operative procedure if there is a concern regarding the patients care. ‘Sign Out': Before the patient is discharged from the operating Theatre all members of the operative team must agree that all the patients care is fully documented and that follow up care is agreed before handover is given to Recovery. All drains, catheters, dressings and specimens are accurately recorded. (WHO Safer Surgery Checklist)
Training
No training is required for staff other than already provided to the specialists operating in this area. Mandatory and competencies are assessed and recorded via training manuals.
Anaesthetic trainees will only join the on call rota once they are considered experienced enough for their allocated role, and never prior to achieving their Initial Assessment of Competence (IAC).
Anaesthetic handovers

Anaesthetic handovers take place at 07:45 and 19:45 hours. The On Call Anaesthetists in Training may meet adjacent to the Emergency board, in recovery or in emergency theatre if mid-case. The On Call/ Emergency Theatre Consultant should be immediately available to discuss management plans for complex cases.

The outgoing anaesthetic night team should pre-assess the first two potential patients scheduled for emergency surgery the next day in order for surgery to commence promptly. The roles and plans for the day should be reassigned and discussed at this time.
An additional handover will also be required at 18:00 on weekdays, when the 3rd session emergency anaesthetist takes over from the day-time emergency consultant.
Emergency board meeting

Emergency board meetings take place at 08:00 hours each morning. Emergency Theatre Lead Practitioner, ODPs and Emergency Theatre anaesthetists should attend (in addition to Floor Consultant and duty Band 7 on week days), together with a representative from the surgical specialties. Representatives from the relevant specialties (General Surgery/ Urology/ ENT/ Gynaecology/ Max Fax/ Oral/ Vascular/ Medical) must attend if those speciality patients require procedures.
Orthopaedic and Plastic Consultants do not need to attend as they have their own speciality lists, however if a patient requires an MDT approach then they may be required.

This meeting will identify individual patients' clinical needs, their preparedness for surgery, anaesthesia and post-surgical care. (e.g. ITU bed, extended Recovery stay) and ensure the correct information is available to the whole emergency team).

At the Emergency Board Meeting the clinical priority will be decided for the specialities, (see 12.4). There are usually 2 x Theatres allocated for emergency surgery from 08:00 to 17:30 hours Monday to Friday, but 1 x Theatre is available with 24/7 access.

The Emergency Board Meeting does not replace the Team Brief for each theatre, where the operating surgeon, anaesthetist and theatre team should discuss each patient, as per the WHO checklist. This should usually occur before patients are sent for, to ensure all appropriate staff and equipment are available, except in life- threatening emergency situations. Additional Team Briefs will need to be held during the day as new cases are added to the emergency lists.

It is the responsibility of the Consultant Anaesthetist allocated to emergencies to ensure that, at the start of the day, any relevant information is handed over from the Consultant Anaesthetist who has been on call overnight.

At the evening handover at 19:45 hours the overnight plan will be discussed. It is recognised the list may change depending on clinical priority and additional patients that are added to the emergency list.
Staffing
The Emergency Theatre Team will include the following.
Team Leader /Co-ordinator (Band 6 or above).
Scrub Nurse/Practitioner.
Circulating Nurse/Practitioner.
Anaesthetic Operating Department Practitioner (ODP)/ Nurse.
Anaesthetic Trainee on call.
Anaesthetic Consultant (present or immediately available).
On Call Surgical Speciality Team.
Safety briefings

The safety briefings will include personal introductions, planning the list order, discussion of each patient booked for a procedure, including any anticipated hazards. The need for additional resources (e.g. radiography) and the need for breaks/ change of staffing, if applicable, should be discussed at this time.
High risk patients

Patients identified as being at high risk either by clinical assessment or by physiological scoring, should be highlighted to the Theatre team at the time of the WHO pre-list safety briefing. It is expected that a Consultant Surgeon and Consultant Anaesthetist be involved in the management of high risk patients. Such patients should be discussed with the Critical Care team regarding their post- operative care when necessary.
Booking system

The online booking system (Theatreman) should be used for booking all procedures. It is the responsibility of the speciality SHO or member of the team to deliver a hand written list to Theatre reception (Monday to Friday) or the Theatre co- coordinator (out of hours) so that this may be entered on the system.

No patient can be booked without first discussing with the anaesthetic team. For emergency laparotomy / laparoscopy patients their NELA scores must be calculated to ensure the correct risk stratification and preparation according to best practice guidelines.

Patients may occasionally need to be booked for the emergency lists on other days due to requirement for specialist skills, availability of equipment or when less urgent cases are rolled over due to lack of time. There should be active review of these patients each day by contacting the ward and surgical team to ensure the plan is still appropriate, with active removal from the list if surgery no longer needed or appropriate.

It is the responsibility of the Theatre team to ensure all equipment is available before the patient is sent for. If the equipment is not available then the appropriate staff must be contacted to provide advice.
Paper booking forms should be used if there is a failure of the electronic booking system.

Patients requiring immediate transfer to Theatre for a procedure should have a booking request completed retrospectively. This will only apply to patients transferred from ITU or ED or emergencies from wards.

Patients booked for Theatre must be clerked, correctly consented, appropriately starved and ready to come to Theatre. Procedures should not be booked until the need for the procedure is confirmed and all necessary tests/ preparation is completed. This applies to all patients except those requiring life or limb saving surgery.
Who operates when

Although the Emergency Theatre is staffed 24 hours a day it is recognised that human and system factors mean that surgery is safer when performed at times when fatigue is minimal, and support systems are optimal. In practice this means that only life threatening or limb saving surgery should be performed “in the middle of the night”. It is left at the discretion of the wider Emergency Team (including Surgeons, Anaesthetists and Emergency Team Leader) to assess whether surgery can be done safely.
At all times patient safety is the priority. Non urgent surgery should be performed before midnight and the best interests of the patient considered (NCEPOD).

The Emergency Theatre lists will be allocated according to clinical priority irrespective of specialty. When the clinical priority order is unclear or challenged, it is the responsibility of the consultants of the respective surgical teams to talk to each other and come to an agreement.
At the Emergency Board Meeting the clinical priority will be decided for cases from all specialities:
ENT.
Maxillofacial.
Urology.
Gynaecology.
Vascular.
Head and neck.
General.
Ophthalmology.
Patients that are not ready for Theatre at the allotted time will be substituted for the next patient on the list.
Orthopaedic trauma theatre and emergency theatre
NHS Local Safety Standards for Invasive Procedures to be applied in every case when emergency surgery is required.

Where no trauma list is available, or where the number of patients requiring urgent Orthopaedic surgery exceeds the capacity of the trauma list then an assessment is made of the elective procedures which can be booked to another time.
Plastics trauma, Burns and other emergencies are not expected to impact on Orthopaedic trauma unless clinical need and staffing affect how patients may be treated.

Maternity Theatre is independently staffed and co-ordinated and should not be affected by this policy, please refer to the Maternity Theatres Clinical Operational Policy No; 10030, found on the intranet.
Opening an additional emergency theatre
If a patient requires a urgent/ emergency procedure performed at a time when the emergency Theatre is already in use, the Theatre Co-Ordinator and Anaesthetic On Call / Floor Consultant is contacted.

If staffing levels allow, an additional operating Theatre may be made available. The decision to open an additional Theatre should be made jointly by the Consultant Surgeon, Consultant Anaesthetist and Theatre Co-ordinator.
Where the need is urgent and there is no other Theatre available, the decision to stop an elective list will be taken by Floor Consultants and the Theatre Co- Ordinator.
External emergencies/ transfers

Occasionally assistance of the Emergency team may be required where patients require the specialist skill of an Anaesthetist and ODP e.g. to safely transfer a patient to another hospital or to manage a sick child in Resus.
If the On Call Anaesthetist and ODP are required to undertake a task outside theatre (e.g. an inter-hospital transfer), where possible, staff replacements should

be found to ensure that the Emergency Theatre remains available for operating. Only life and limb saving surgery will continue until team return if adequate resources cannot be allocated from elsewhere. The Consultant Anaesthetist may need to be present on site whilst the team are busy/ on the transfer and will liaise with the Theatre Team leader regarding the safety of continuing the running of the emergency Theatre.
Every effort must be made to prevent patients both elective and emergency from having any procedure significantly postponed (>12 hours) or cancelled.

Assistance is occasionally requested by ITU, from the emergency theatre anaesthetic team, to help with transfers of intubated patients within the hospital (to CT/ MRI etc.). This assistance can be given when there is no one with the appropriate skills available in ITU and it can be managed without compromising the running of the emergency theatre.
Auditing recovery and the emergency theatre

It is important that the length of time between procedures is kept to a minimum. This will be audited through regular reporting from staff involved and through electronic data that is provided. These will be reviewed by the Theatre Manager for Theatres.

Patient safety is a priority at all times and outside of normal elective working hours, emergency surgery is prioritised by the Consultant Anaesthetist and the Specialists for the area. When it is required on call teams are available.

AFPP Guidelines are followed to ensure safe staffing levels in Theatre are provided at all times including out of hours. Any significant incidences that impact upon out of hours working would be recorded and reported via the incident reporting system that is part of the Governance structure.
Breaches
Where breaches of this policy occur that are identified within the groups below, an Incident Report (DATIX) form must be completed.
Failure in communication.
Failure of staff groups to participate in any briefings related to the emergency list.
Any issue relating to staffing or equipment that impacts on the uninterrupted running of the Emergency list.
Each incident report will be investigated and fed back to the relevant staff groups individually by the Lead Practitioner for Theatres.
Rest and fatigue
Whenever possible, breaks should be taken when natural breaks occur between procedures.
When multiple procedures are scheduled the Emergency Team Leader/ Co- Ordinator and Floor / On Call Consultant will be responsible for facilitating cover to provide staff with adequate rest.
Major incidents - role of department
In the event of a major incident, the maximum number of Theatres will be made available as soon as possible.
Routine operating will cease. Facilities for emergency surgery on patients already scheduled will continue and be prioritised using the Major Incident Triage System.
The hospital emergency plans will cover all emergencies during this period.
The Theatre Manager or nominated Deputy will be based in the Main Theatre Unit and will be responsible for control and reporting during this time.
Quality assurance and improvement
Delays in operating are associated with adverse outcomes (NCEPOD). Patients that have urgent surgery delayed >24 hours without clinical reason should be reported as adverse incidents.
The Anaesthetic department recommends the following are monitored for effectiveness:
Level of supervision during out of hours and emergency cases.
Timing of emergencies on the 24 hour clock.
Adequacy of resuscitation before emergency surgery.
Management of the emergency laparotomy.
Emergency provision of blood and blood products.
Management of the morbidly obese patient requiring emergency surgery.
Management of patients for fractured neck of femur patients.
Anaesthetic emergency-drugs and equipment preparedness.
ICU/HDU admission after surgery.
Instant report to be completed when patient care is affected.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring

Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Compliance with National Guidelines: National Emergency Laparotomy Audit
Trust NELA Lead (Dr S. Sothisrihar i)

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Anaesthetics and Theatres Governance Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Surgery/ Anaesthetics and Theatres guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Anaesthetics and Theatres Governance Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)

https://www.ncepod.org.uk/2003wow.html

https://www.nela.org.uk/
